mods.abstract: Elise Croft shares why the Crofts moved to Cuba and why she still feels a strong connection to the country. Also heard on the tape are Margaret Croft, Joe Thompson Jr., and Mary Hamilton Thompson Orr.

William Croft moved to Cuba in 1900 and started the General Concrete Construction Company of Cuba in Havana. The company specialized in the construction of concrete chimneys for the sugar industry on the island. After Mr. Croft's death in 1938, his daughters Elise and Margaret became sole owners of the company's stocks and relied on income from the company for their livelihood. Elise visited Cuba at least once a year on business through the 1950s and kept up a regular correspondence with company manager Bradford Dallas. On December 6, 1961, all of the Croft's property in Cuba, including the company, was confiscated pursuant to Law 989 - the abandoned property law issued by Fidel Castro (1926-2016). The Croft sisters filed a claim with the United States Government in the late 1960s, but never received compensation for their losses. Their claims against the Cuban government are still outstanding.
